body:
https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/d430c63460073b16049d506b05c82751f041d84e/junit-platform-reporting/src/main/java/org/junit/platform/reporting/legacy/xml/XmlReportWriter.java#L220

The message string of the throwable is passed as-is to the XML stream writer. The message is generated via `String.format("expected: <%s> but was: <%s>", expectedString, actualString);` [AssertionUtils.java#L122](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/d430c63460073b16049d506b05c82751f041d84e/junit-jupiter-api/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/api/AssertionUtils.java#L122) -- and some characters (`<`, `>`) are escaped. `\0` is not.

Some quick research reveals that the `NUL` character is simply [not supported in XML 1.0 and 1.1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valid_characters_in_XML#Characters_allowed_but_discouraged).

> Note that the code point U+0000, assigned to the null control character, is the only character encoded in Unicode and ISO/IEC 10646 that is always invalid in any XML 1.0 and 1.1 document.

How about simply using `assertTrue(...)` for such use cases in order to avoid inclusion of the `NUL` character in the generated XML report?

For example...

```java
assertTrue("A".equals("B\0"), "\"A\".equals(\"B\\0\")");
```

That results in error message like this:

```
org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: "A".equals("B\0") ==> expected: <true> but was: <false>
```

the above is a very simplified example: actually the data was read from a file and the `\0` was missed in the cleaning, and the created XML-File was not readable, which gave a cryptic message in the system that runs the tests. So nobody expected the `\0`... and one breaking test gave an invalid file which was interpreted as a lot of failed tests. 
And the system is a grading software (https://inginious.readthedocs.io/en/v0.6/teacher_doc/what_is_inginious.html) and the "0 pts" resulted in a very unhappy student ;-)

> the "0 pts" resulted in a very unhappy student ;-)

Yes, I can imagine. 

Thanks for providing further details.

We'll see if we can improve the situation.

issue.title: Replace illegal chars with their char reference

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Prior to this commit, characters not allowed according to the XML 1.0
spec where written to the XML reports if present in exception messages
etc. Now, we detect them and replace them with their character
reference.

Fixes #2269.

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
- [x] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass

body: thanks a lot for the quick fix
@AugustH Are you okay with using a snapshot for the time being? We don't intend to publish a bugfix release for this issue since it's really an edge case.
no problem, my students are instructed to avoid the problem. But it is fixed for the class. Thanks again
